ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REDUCTION OF CITY COUNCIL 1959 EXPENDITURE


    1. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Prime Minister to state the amount of reduction of the City Council 1959 expenditure occasioned by the cut in variable allowance.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply.

Column: 812



    The cut in the variable allowances was made in the City Council as from 1st July, 1959. For the six-month period, the savings are approximately $849,000.

    As from 1st January, 1960, the technical and professional allowances that will be paid to Government servants will also be paid to City Council officers who qualify under the rules. Therefore, the savings for 1960 will be somewhat less. It is not possible to assess now how much will be paid out in these technical and professional allowances.

NICOLL HIGHWAY PROMENADE DEVELOPMENT
OLD KALLANG AIRPORT PARK DEVELOPMENT
(National Construction Corps)


    2. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for National Development, with reference to the Nicoll Highway Promenade Development and the Old Kallang Airport Park Development, to state-

    (a) how much of the labour cost of each of the projects was paid to members of the National Construction Corps;

    (b) how many of such members of the National Construction Corps were members of the People's Action Party;

    (c) how many of such members of National Construction Corps were unemployed; and

    (d) what information was publicly given in the press or otherwise that such members of the National Construction Corps would be paid an allowance of $3.00 a day for their expenses.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, I should first explain that the National Construction Corps consists of two types of workers: (1) members of the general public who volunteer for work on various projects and receive no payment of any kind; and (2) members of the

Column: 813

Special Squad which forms the hardcore of the Corps, all of whom are paid $3 a day to cover expenses. Whenever delay occurs on any project, the Special Squad is called upon to expedite the work.

    I presume the hon. Member for Mountbatten is concerned only with the Special Squad as seen in the various questions asked, and the replies to the various questions are as follows:

    To Question (a), the following payments were made to members of the Special Squad:- 

    Nicoll Highway project       $4,660.05



    Kallang Park project        $73,506.00


    To Question (b), the Special Squad at present has about 700 members and of this number about half are members of the People's Action Party. I should mention here that many of the members of the Special Squad have applied for membership in the P.A.P. after joining the Special Squad. We have made this open.

    To Question (c), about 95 per cent of the P.A.P. members were unemployed at the time they joined the Special Squad.

    To Question (d), as the hon. Member for Mountbatten is aware, I myself announced in this House on 25th November, 1959, that members of the Special Squad would be paid $3 a day for their expenses. As far as I am aware, no other public announcement has been made in this connection.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I assume that none of those 700 members knew, the day before they started work, that they were going to be paid?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, all of them knew they would be paid $3 a day as allowances.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, would it be too much to ask how they knew, because there was no public announcement at all until the 25th November when it was announced in this

Column: 814

House? Before then, there was no announcement. How did they know they were going to be paid?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, my belief is that the - hon. Member for Mountbatten has not been following closely the activities of the Special Squad. If I could only ask her and many other Members on the Opposition Benches to come one day and have a look at the Special Squad. But since none of them has given even an hour to the construction projects which we have at Kallang Park, the Promenade, and Changi beach, I hope they can join the Special Squad tomorrow, or the day after, or at some convenient time of their choosing, and work in places like opening parks at Hong Lim Green, Havelock Park, Elgin Bridge, swamp reclamation, construction of roads and bridges and standpipes. And if they do such kind of work, I am sure, Mr Speaker, they will have a better insight into the activities and follow more closely the activities of the Special Squad.

    When the Special Squad was formed, it was decided that they should be paid $3 a day, and from the day when it was formed under my Ministry, they were paid $3 a day. It was not necessary to announce that we were paying them $3 a day, because these people were not public servants and there was no necessity for making public announcements on the detailed administrative work that the Government was doing, as it was a physical impossibility.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, may I refer him to the people recruited to this National Construction Corps? Would the Minister please state whether the Labour Exchange has been consulted? As we all know, Sir, the Labour Exchange has about 45,000 registered unemployed.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, the People's Action Party Government believes in doing things openly and honourably. The Special Squad is necessary because in any construction work, we need a-

Column: 815



    Mr Speaker: Order. I must remind the Minister that we are not in a debate, and the questions ask for brief answers and to the point.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: I am sorry, Mr Speaker. The recruitment of members of the Special Squad was not done through the Labour Exchange, because we believe in doing the things honestly and openly in order to achieve certain desired objectives - in this case, the construction of important projects.

    It was a different position when the Member for Cairnhill was the Chief Minister of the previous government during which period he formed his unemployment squad. We openly state that we are going to recruit members from our Party who would be trained in order to lead the National Construction Corps for our special projects.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, do I understand aright when the Minister said that, because he did not consult the Labour Exchange, it was therefore done honestly and openly?

    Mr Speaker: I think we are embarking on a debate! Perhaps the hon. Member could pursue the matter further on the adjournment or by way of a motion.

    Mrs Seow, question 3, please.

COMMUNITY CENTRES AND YOUTH ORGANISATIONS


    3. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Labour and Law, with regard to the reorganisation of Community Centres and Youth Organisations as announced by the Government five months ago, what progress has been made in such reorganisation; and whether Members of the Assembly are now expected and encouraged to participate in the activities of the Community Centres and Youth Organisations in their respective Constituencies.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Department of Social Welfare has taken over control of all Social Welfare community centres and Rural Board

Column: 816

community centres. It is in the process of taking over the Singapore Improvement Trust community centres, and work has been started on two small-sized community centres and one medium-sized community centre. The centralisation of all community centres under a single organisation is making progress and will not be completed until all new community centres planned by Government are built. With the winding up of the Singapore Youth Council, the responsibility for co-ordinating all youth activities now rests with the Singapore Council of Social Service.

    Members of the Assembly can participate in the activities of community centres and youth organisations, provided they do not force their way in and are acceptable to the great majority of those enjoying these amenities and do not use these centres for political propaganda.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [25th November, 1959], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1960."

    Question again proposed.

2.56 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the first Budget of the P.A.P. Government, but there is nothing in it for the P.A.P. to crow about. In fact, any other Government would have made the same, if not better, provisions for improvement in the social services.

    There is, however, Sir, one fundamental difference, and this is the manner in which the tools of Government machinery are put to use. They believe, Sir, that to give better service to the people, civil

Column: 820

servants should have their total emoluments reduced arbitrarily. They believe, Sir, that to give better education to the children, teachers should be treated in such a manner that many have now resigned. They believe too, Sir, that to give better medical attention to the people, doctors should be treated in such a manner that many doctors have now resigned. And they believe that, to give better housing to the people, architects, engineers and others should be treated in such a shameful way that many architects, engineers and others have resigned. They believe that, to give the workers a better deal, trade unions should be brought under firm control so that they will not behave in the manner that the P.A.P. -dominated unions in the past were wont to behave. They believe that, to win over the confidence of capital for the economic development of Singapore, capital should be first frightened away by the utterances of threats during election campaigns and later coaxed by assurances that there would be no increased taxation, and that the Government would, by the exercise of firm control on trade unions, see that there is no industrial strife when the Party got into power.

    Sir, we do not subscribe to these beliefs. In fact, we abhor such beliefs because they are damaging to the interests of the people of Singapore.

    Sir, the Minister for Finance said, and I quote from Hansard, column 772:

    "An elected Government which enjoys the support of the mass of the people must have objectives basically different from the Government that it replaced."

Sir, if by objective is meant the many beliefs that I have just related, then they can have this claim without challenge. But I think the Minister means it to mean the provisions in his Budget. In this I can see no basic difference, apart from one important aspect. He has submitted a deficit budget of $6 million; he has indicated in his speech of applications for supplementary votes in the coming months, thereby increasing the deficit; and yet he has taken no step

Column: 821

whatsoever to meet this deficit by increasing taxation on those who can bear it.

    It is clear, Sir, that they have now come to the realisation that to save Singapore from economic disaster, they have to re-adjust their attitude towards capital to repair the great damage which they did by the utterances of their threats during the election campaign. They are now anxious - very, very anxious indeed - Sir, to win over the confidence of capital to help them to run the government.

    Sir, in the 1959 standstill budget, there was a deficit of about $4 million, and yet we, who had been accused by the P.A.P. as capitalist stooges, introduced increased income tax in the higher brackets and company tax in order to meet this deficit. This was done at a time when we had to face the impending general elections.

    Sir, the Minister for Finance has announced one tax proposal. That is the imposition of port dues. About this, let us see what he has to say. Column 805 of the Hansard reads:

    "The port dues envisaged, however, will be modest ones and shipping interests will be fully consulted before they are implemented."

    I repeat, Sir:

    "Shipping interests will be fully consulted before they are implemented."

    This is the right step and is another indication that they do not want to offend capital any more. It would have been a good thing, Sir, for all concerned, if they had only followed this same step by consulting fully the Staff Side instead of imposing arbitrarily the cuts in variable allowances. Capital must be treated gently, but civil servants - they are after all wage earners - should go on their bended knees that worse has not befallen upon them.

    Sir, the Minister for Finance in the earlier part of his speech devoted six paragraphs to his appraisal of the economic situation in the Federation of Malaya. We all know that the Federation is now enjoying a period of steady progress. But this cannot be said of Singapore. There seems to be a spirit of

Column: 822

despondency, not only in business circles -

    An hon. Member: But in the Opposition!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: -but throughout the country. Therefore, Sir, any move by the Government to inject confidence and a buoyant spirit into the economic life of Singapore is to be welcomed even by the Opposition. The proposal to form a commodity common market with the Federation of Malaya is indeed a good one and I wish the Minister every success.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Why did you not try to do it?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: In regard to Indonesia, Sir, I am glad that relations with Indonesia have immensely improved. This is all to the good and I hope that it will lead to the early removal of the severe restrictions on imports imposed by the Indonesian Government.

    Sir, the Minister for Finance said that there was a major building boom in Kuala Lumpur. But the building trade in Singapore, however, went through a difficult period. Surely, the Minister knows where the blame lies.

    In his financial review of 1959, the Minister has quoted figures which I find it difficult to reconcile. On the one hand, he said that a shortfall of $10 million on the tobacco revenue was expected. He made no mention of other shortfalls. On the other hand, he said that if the Government had not acted as promptly and as decisively as it did - and this, of course, refers, among other things, to the increased tobacco and petrol duties and the imposition of a tax on the hire of films - there would be $4 million in revenue shortfall. First, the Minister said that there would be a shortfall of $10 million and in just under two minutes I think, this shortfall had been reduced to $4 million. Sir, the 1959 budget estimated a total revenue of $265 million. The Minister in his speech said that the revised estimates showed that the 1959 revenue would amount to $258 million, whereas on page 16 of Cmd.

Column: 823

(New Series) 32, the revised estimated total revenue is given as $259.2 million. Sir, accepting the Minister's statement of $258 million as correct, although it is actually $259.2 million, there is, therefore, a shortfall of $7 million. The Minister said that if the Government had not acted as promptly and as decisively as it did, the shortfalls would amount to $4 million. We know that the Government did act promptly and decisively by increasing the tobacco and petrol duties and by imposing a tax on the hire of films. But what I cannot understand is why, in spite of this prompt and decisive action, the shortfall is estimated to be $7 million. If they had taken no action, it is $4 million. Because they had taken this decisive and prompt action, it rose to $7 million! Perhaps the Minister will try to explain.

    Sir, I base my speech not on what is in the budget but on what the Minister himself said in presenting the budget. I would urge upon the Minister that when he moves any motion in this House, he should be more attentive to the facts and figures and not expect the Opposition to wade through a mass of figures in order to find out where he has gone wrong.

    Sir, the Minister said in col. 776 of Hansard:

    "For Singapore, the year 1959 had been a period of some uncertainty. The first half of the year was notable for a general attitude of wait-and-see adopted by business enterprises. It was a period of comparative stagnation. The reason was of course the impending general elections, scheduled to take place in May."

    Sir, nothing can be more true. But let us examine the real reason for this stagnation and for this wait-and-see policy. This was because of the silly utterances of threats issued by P.A.P. leaders during the election campaign. And it is because of these silly utterances that business enterprises called a halt and some of them even removed to Kuala Lumpur. Now the Government is making strenuous efforts to repair this damage by giving assurances of no increased taxation. I have found, Sir, that capital is less concerned with making

Column: 824

more profits; what it desires most of all is a healthy political climate, and so long as the climate is right, business enterprises will remain and will expand.

    Sir, I see that the task of promoting the visitor industry has been transferred from the Ministry of Finance to the Ministry of Culture. The Minister for Finance describes this particular important and growing industry as "the task of luring tourists to our shores". And because he considers that tourists have to be lured and not attracted, it is but right that it should be transferred to the Ministry of Culture. I do not think, Sir, that Government is serious about the promotion of the tourist industry. The budget provisions do not provide for a senior officer who knows this particular job and I would urge upon the Government that, as the tourist industry is a growing and profitable one, it should look into and strengthen this particular section in the Ministry of Culture.

    Sir, as regards the estimated revenue for 1960, the Minister is rather optimistic as this is based on the same rates of taxation in all fields. He has estimated the yield from Income Tax to be $65 million, and although this is $11 million less than that collected for 1959, I feel, Sir, that he has underestimated the adverse trading conditions this year. The economy of Singapore has suffered a great blow as a result of loss of confidence among business circles.

    Sir, as regards revenue from petrol, although the duty is now 20 cents a gallon higher than it was a few months ago, there is a downward trend of consumption brought about by economic circumstances. Less and less people are using their motor-cars for rides.

    Sir, the Minister expects to collect $43.1 million from tobacco, and this figure is about $9 million more than in 1959. The Minister has said that this is based on certain assumptions about consumer preferences but he is not so confident that these assumptions will be justified. He is not so sure of the types of cigarettes people will smoke in 1960.

Column: 825

Will they smoke more imported cigarettes which are dearer, or will they smoke more locally manufactured cigarettes which are cheaper? That is the question. Sir, I say that the Minister is rather optimistic, but then, who knows, trade may pick up next year, particularly as the Government is now repenting the silly utterances of threats during the election campaign and is going all out to win over the confidence of capital.

    Sir, I am glad to see that the Prime Minister has taken over the direction of the City Council. This has caused a great measure of relief to the suffering public, and I wish to congratulate the Prime Minister for taking this move. It is a matter for regret that he did not do it earlier.

    Sir, I agree with the Minister for Finance when he said that the process of integration must be carried out in stages, and that the help of outside experts should be sought. I am anxious, Sir, that the gradual integration will not be to the detriment of the City Council employees. I would like to receive an assurance from the Government, in the same manner as the Honourable the Minister for Finance has hastened to assure the Civil Service, that such integration would not lead to an extensive retrenchment of personnel and that holders of posts found redundant and thereby abolished will be given every opportunity for transfer without loss of emoluments.

    Sir, in regard to that part of the Minister's speech on the Development Estimates. I will touch upon this during the Committee stage; but there are certain points in his speech I would like to mention now. It is clear, Sir, from his speech that there is no possibility that the Development Estimates will be put to full use in 1960, bearing in mind that engineers, architects and others have been driven to resign, leaving the Public Works Department and the S.I.T. with only a handful. This is indeed a setback to the Government, but this is of their own seeking.

    Sir, the building of more schools, more hospitals, more clinics, more houses, and so on, if done by the P.A.P., is described by the Minister for Finance as adding

Column: 826

to the accumulation of wealth in this country and strengthening the sinews of economy. But when the same kind of development was carried out by a non-P.A.P. government, it is described as wasteful expenditure and a strain on the economy of the country.

    The Prime Minister: That proves you are wrong!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: The Minister, Sir, admits that the Government has to go overseas to recruit the expert know-how to help them run the Economic Development Board. I can see nothing wrong in this. It is indeed a very wise move to recruit the expert knowhow from overseas to help them run this very important Board, but I cannot understand, Sir, why the Minister should have spent so much time to explain why this Government has found it necessary to do so. It would appear from his speech that there is a group of people in the P.A.P. perhaps, Sir, who are against this sensible and realistic policy, and in this connection the Minister said (col. 797):

    "To these people, we can say with perfect candour that members of the P.A.P. political leadership are not lacking in talent, vigour or self-confidence. A combination of these qualities, however, may well lead to recklessness bred out of arrogance and ignorance if it is not tempered with a sense of realism."

    "A combination of these qualities, however, may well lead to recklessness bred out of arrogance and ignorance if it is not tempered with a sense of realism." Sir, the cat is out of the bag. Recklessness has been displayed by some Party leaders, bred out of arrogance and ignorance not tempered with any sense of realism!

    Sir, the Minister for Finance has indicated that there will be further claims on the revenue next year by way of applications for supplementary votes. One of these foreseen items of expenditure is the question of a grant to the Nanyang University. I would urge upon the Government to expedite consideration of the Report of the Commission of Inquiry under the chairmanship of Dr Gwee Ah Leng. It is important that an early decision be reached. Sir, we did not appoint Dr Gwee Ah Leng. Dr Gwee Ah Leng was appointed during this session [Interruption]-
